examples: I stopped at the traffic lights.
The riots stopped when police moved in.

definitions.definition: To cause (something) to cease moving or progressing .
examples: The sight of the armed men stopped him in his tracks.
This guy is a fraudster. I need to stop the cheque I wrote him.

definitions.definition: To cease ; to no longer continue (doing something, especially something wrong or undesirable, or something causing irritation or annoyance).
examples: One of the wrestlers suddenly stopped fighting.
Don't let me stop you working.

definitions.definition: To cause (something) to come to an end .
To close or block an opening .
examples: He stopped the wound with gauze.
Rotten leaves and branches have stopped the gutter.
I've had the cracks in the wall stopped with mortar by the builders.

definitions.definition: To adjust the aperture of a camera lens .
examples: To achieve maximum depth of field, he stopped down to an f-stop of 22.
definitions.label_groups: transitive , intransitive , photography , often with "up" or "down"

definitions.definition: To stay ; to spend a short time ; to reside or tarry temporarily.
examples: He stopped for two weeks at the inn.
He stopped at his friend's house before continuing with his drive.

definitions.definition: To regulate the sounds of (musical strings, etc.) by pressing them against the fingerboard with the finger, or otherwise shortening the vibrating part.
To pronounce (a phoneme) as a stop.
To delay the purchase or sale of (a stock ) while agreeing the price for later.

secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To cause (something) to cease moving or progressing .
( transitive ) To cease ; to no longer continue (doing something, especially something wrong or undesirable, or something causing irritation or annoyance).
( transitive ) To cause (something) to come to an end .
( causative , transitive , chiefly UK ) To end someone else's activity.
( transitive ) To close or block an opening .
( transitive , intransitive , photography , often with "up" or "down" ) To adjust the aperture of a camera lens .
( intransitive ) To stay ; to spend a short time ; to reside or tarry temporarily.
( music ) To regulate the sounds of (musical strings, etc.) by pressing them against the fingerboard with the finger, or otherwise shortening the vibrating part.
( nautical ) To make fast ; to stopper .
( phonetics , transitive ) To pronounce (a phoneme) as a stop.
( finance , transitive ) To delay the purchase or sale of (a stock ) while agreeing the price for later.
